awd_titl_txt: Imaging Vertical Earthquake Cycle Crustal Deformation of the San Andreas Fault System Utilizing the GAGE Facility
awd_abstract_narration:
Major earthquakes along the San Andreas Fault system in southern California threaten millions of people and billions of dollars in property and infrastructure, which makes understanding the physics of earthquakes key in addressing a critical societal need for improved seismic hazard estimates.  This project is using state-of-the-art geodetic data provided by the GAGE (Geodesy Advancing Geosciences and EarthScope) Facility and EarthScope to understand how Earth's crust deforms in response to plate tectonics and other processes.  The project is focused particularly on understanding vertical motions, which may be related to groundwater withdrawal and snow loading and the migration, extraction, and injection of crustal fluids in addition to faulting and earthquake processes. Detection of anomalous vertical motions in these data will not only improve the quality of earthquake cycle strain rate estimates, but is also a valuable resource for climate, hydrologic, oceanographic, and earthquake engineering communities.

The team is focusing on studying vertical deformation using a synthesis of GAGE Facility (Global Positioning System and InSAR) and coastal tide gauge data spanning the Pacific-North American plate boundary. The project is developing well-constrained time-series model products of 3D earthquake cycle deformation using integrated high accuracy GPS point measurements, high spatial resolution InSAR measurements, and long-period tide gauge vertical time series observations. This research project has four main objectives: (1) preparing a contemporary high-resolution GPS-constrained 4D model of vertical and horizontal crustal deformation of the SAFS; (2) using these models to correct  inherent errors in InSAR data from new satellites through integrated analysis of GPS and InSAR; (3) construction of a refined 4D time series of crustal deformation derived GPS, InSAR, and tide gauge time-series data; and (4) detecting and understanding  non-tectonic deformation common in both InSAR and GPS data.  In addition, the team is developing outreach materials describing how InSAR observations are made and used in modeling crustal deformation and distributing those via the Active Earth kiosks supported by NSF, and is releasing software tools to enable geodetic data analyses by the broad Earth science community.

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
The San Andreas Fault System (SAFS) is comprised of a complex network of fault segments that extend nearly 1,200 kilometers through California. The SAFS's potential to cause unprecedented economic and infrastructure damage, as well as human loss, among the over 10 million people who live in the region, underlines the immediate need to advance ways in which we study and quantify the region?s seismic hazards. While the timing of the next major earthquake is largely unpredictable, the earthquake potential along the faults can be accurately estimated by measuring the seismic moment accumulation rate and when multiplied by the time since the last major rupture, can be a measure of potential earthquake magnitude.  Furthermore, time dependent processes that span the earthquake cycle can be imaged using observations from the Global Navigation Satellite System (GNSS, or GPS) and radar interferometry (InSAR) and used to determine physical properties of the crust (like depths and rates of tectonic strain accumulation) that further help resolve levels of seismic hazard along the fault system. New to this work is the application of vertical motion data, combined with modeling tools that explore variations in rheology, to advance our understanding of how Earth deforms in both horizontal and vertical directions.  Detection of anomalous vertical motions in the crustal deformation record can not only improve the quality of earthquake cycle strain rate estimates, but is also a valuable resource for climate, hydrologic, oceanographic, and earthquake engineering communities. 

We proposed the following tasks:

  • Develop a contemporary high-resolution 4D model of vertical and horizontal crustal deformation of the San Andreas Fault System 
  • Use this model to correct InSAR data errors from new satellites using a GNSS/InSAR integration method
  • Construct a refined 4D time-series model constrained by continuous GNSS, InSAR, and tide gauge time-series data
  • Detect and decompose non-tectonic deformation common in both InSAR and GPS data
  • Use these results to educate K-16 students and the Earth Science community on EarthScope data and discoveries of active plate boundary deformation

Our results are provided in 7 peer-reviewed publications (and 1 currently in review) and the InSAR software development supporting this work is available at http://topex.ucsd.edu/gmtsar.  Major outcomes are:

1) A new 3D interseismic deformation model of the San Andreas Fault System where lateral variations in shear modulus are included to simulate lateral variations (rigidity, elastic plate thickness) in lithospheric structure (Sandwell and Smith-Konter, 2018; Ward et al., 2021; Figures 1, 2).

2) A new 4D time-series model of the San Andreas Fault System plate boundary spanning earthquake activity of the last 1000 years (using the latest paleoearthquake data from 31 sites spanning the central and southern SAFS.

3) In response to the 2019 Ridgecrest earthquake sequence, we provided near-real time InSAR line-of-sight displacement maps and 3D deformation/stress models to the earthquake community. These data were posted on our website (https://topex.ucsd.edu/SV_7.1/) and other social media platforms. We also led an analysis of vertical deformation GNSS time series to investigate postseismic deformation mechanisms following the 2019 Ridgecrest earthquake (Xu et al., 2019; Dawson et al., 2019; Ponti et al., 2020; Xu et al., 2020; Ward et al., 2022) (Figure 3).

4) New software to advance our studies of crustal deformation and moment accumulation.   The maxwell computer code is available on GitHub (Sandwell and Smith-Konter, 2018).

The intellectual merit of this investigation was to obtain an improved understanding of the crustal loading and release processes associated with the earthquake cycle, and to further explore these processes using vertical geodetic data.  The broader impacts of this investigation are to estimate the earthquake potential of the faults along the SAFS, as well as to train the next generation of science and technical leaders. A significant component of our research emphasized Earth Science education through the Earth Moves Me! program and distribution of model products within the scientific community. 

Selected Publications:

Ward, L., Guns, K., B. Smith-Konter, X. Xu, Y. Bock, D.T. Sandwell (2022), Vertical postseismic deformation of the 2019 Ridgecrest Earthquake sequence, JGR, 2021JB023331.

Ward, L., B. Smith-Konter, X. Xu, X. Tong, and D.T. Sandwell (2021), Seismic moment dependence on crustal rigidity for the southern San Andreas Fault System, JGR, https://doi. org/10.1029/2020JB021208 

Xu, X., D.T. Sandwell, L. Ward, C. Milliner, B. Smith-Konter, P. Feng, and Y. Bock (2020), Surface deformation associated with fractures near the 2019 Ridgecrest earthquake sequence, Science, 370, https://doi:10.1126/science.abd1690.

 Xu, X., D.T. Sandwell, and B. Smith-Konter (2019), Co-seismic displacements and surface fractures from Sentinel-1 InSAR: 2019 Ridgecrest Earthquakes, SRL, 91 (4), https://doi.org/10.1785/0220190275.

Sandwell, D.T. and B. Smith-Konter (2018), Maxwell:  A semi-analytic 4-D code for earthquake cycle modeling of transform fault systems, Comp Geosciences, doi: 10.1016/j.cageo.2017.737.

Modified by: Bridget R Smith-Konter

por.por_txt_cntn:
The San Andreas Fault System (SAFS) is comprised of a complex network of fault segments that extend nearly 1,200 kilometers through California. The SAFS's potential to cause unprecedented economic and infrastructure damage, as well as human loss, among the over 10 million people who live in the region, underlines the immediate need to advance ways in which we study and quantify the region?s seismic hazards. While the timing of the next major earthquake is largely unpredictable, the earthquake potential along the faults can be accurately estimated by measuring the seismic moment accumulation rate and when multiplied by the time since the last major rupture, can be a measure of potential earthquake magnitude. New to this work is the application of vertical motion data, combined with modeling tools that explore variations in rheology, to advance our understanding of how Earth deforms in both horizontal and vertical directions.  Detection of anomalous vertical motions in the crustal deformation record can not only improve the quality of earthquake cycle strain rate estimates, but is also a valuable resource for climate, hydrologic, oceanographic, and earthquake engineering communities. 

We proposed the following tasks:

Develop a contemporary high-resolution 4D model of vertical and horizontal crustal deformation of the San Andreas Fault System 
Use this model to correct InSAR data errors from new satellites using a GNSS/InSAR integration method
Construct a refined 4D time-series model constrained by continuous GNSS, InSAR, and tide gauge time-series data
Detect and decompose non-tectonic deformation common in both InSAR and GPS data
Use these results to educate K-16 students and the Earth Science community on EarthScope data and discoveries of active plate boundary deformation


Our results are provided in 7 peer-reviewed publications (and 1 currently in review) and the InSAR software development supporting this work is available at http://topex.ucsd.edu/gmtsar.  Major outcomes are:

1) A new 3D interseismic deformation model of the San Andreas Fault System where lateral variations in shear modulus are included to simulate lateral variations (rigidity, elastic plate thickness) in lithospheric structure (Sandwell and Smith-Konter, 2018; Ward et al., 2021; Figures 1, 2).

2) A new 4D time-series model of the San Andreas Fault System plate boundary spanning earthquake activity of the last 1000 years (using the latest paleoearthquake data from 31 sites spanning the central and southern SAFS.

3) In response to the 2019 Ridgecrest earthquake sequence, we provided near-real time InSAR line-of-sight displacement maps and 3D deformation/stress models to the earthquake community. The intellectual merit of this investigation was to obtain an improved understanding of the crustal loading and release processes associated with the earthquake cycle, and to further explore these processes using vertical geodetic data.  The broader impacts of this investigation are to estimate the earthquake potential of the faults along the SAFS, as well as to train the next generation of science and technical leaders. A significant component of our research emphasized Earth Science education through the Earth Moves Me! program and distribution of model products within the scientific community.
